text:
Some time ago, there was a website that talked about the risks of public check-ins. It said that if you post something online, it can be seen by a lot of people. This made people think about the downsides of sharing their lives online. The website also talked about the benefits of sharing online, such as wealth and fame.
There are a lot of people who share their lives online. Some people use social media to share photos and stories. Others use blogs to write about their thoughts and experiences. One person who shared his life online was Justin Hall. He started a blog in 1996 and wrote about his life. He also shared photos and videos. One day, Hall's blog was taken down because someone sent the address of his blog to his boss. This made Hall feel bad, but it also made him realize that sharing your life online can have negative consequences.
Another person who shared her life online was Heather Armstrong. She started a blog called Dooce and wrote about her job at a software company. One day, an anonymous colleague sent the address of Armstrong's blog to every vice president at her company. This made Armstrong lose her job. This showed that sharing your life online can have negative consequences.
However, Armstrong's story also has a happy ending. She was upset by the experience, but she stopped blogging for several months afterwards. She ended up getting married and restarting her blog with a focus on her new family. Today, she is a star in the burgeoning ranks of 'mommy bloggers' and her writing supports her household.

A long time ago, some scientists started a campaign to warn people about a movie called What the Bleep Do We Know. The movie showed that there is a lot about the universe that we don't understand. Some people felt that the movie was dangerous and issued warnings about it. The movie was very popular, but I couldn't see what all the fuss was about at first. However, when the movie moved on to describe some of the new discoveries, I started to see what the fuss was really about. One of the discoveries was that water molecules can be affected by thoughts. I had heard rumours about this before, but the movie gave me some evidence to support it. The evidence was not very convincing, but it was enough to make me believe that the discovery was real. The movie also talked about other discoveries, such as the expansion of the universe and the nature of reality. These discoveries were even more astounding than the discovery of water molecules being affected by thoughts. Despite what some people might believe, science shows no signs of reaching completion. We appear to be further away from omniscience than ever.

Writing novels is like planting a forest, while writing short stories is more like planting a garden. The two processes complement each other, creating a complete landscape. Writing novels takes a long time and requires a lot of commitment, while writing short stories is quicker and easier to complete. You can create a story out of the smallest things and experiment with different ideas. Short stories are like guideposts to your heart, and they can make you happy as a writer.

Science is a powerful force that has greatly impacted human life. It has improved our lives and presented challenges. It has also inspired artists and thinkers. Science has its beauty and its dangers. It has been used to heal diseases and to understand the universe. However, science is not perfect. It has its limitations and its flaws. Scientists are always working to improve their theories and methods. The history of science is filled with examples of scientists who have made significant contributions to the field. Science has also been used to control nature. We have the ability to manipulate the future through science. Therefore, it is important to be aware of the power and potential dangers of science.

From around 2015, major publishers started to report that sales of ebooks had flattened out or even fallen in some cases. This has raised concerns about the long-term potential of ebooks in the publishing industry. Some people believe that the ebooks hype may have driven unwise investment, with companies losing too much confidence in ‘the power of the word on the page’. Despite the evidence suggesting that digital and print can coexist in the market, the question of whether the ebook will ‘kill’ the print book still continues to surface.
The idea of one medium ‘killing’ another has often followed the unveiling of new technologies. Even before the advent of digital technologies, critics have predicted the demise of existing media. For example, when television was invented, many people claimed that radio would die. But radio ended up surviving by finding new uses. The same has happened with other technologies, such as movies, radio, and the phonograph.
The spread of the printing press in 15th-century Europe, the shift from silent to sound movie in the 1920s, and the shift from analog to digital photography have all stimulated nostalgia for older technologies. Not surprisingly, e-readers have stimulated a new appreciation for the material quality of ‘old’ books.
This should provide some reassurance to those who still worry about the disappearance of print books. However, the idea of the disappearing medium will continue to provide an appealing narrative about both the transformative power of technology and our aversion to change.

Every day, I wake up early, brush my teeth, and make coffee. I write about how some of the greatest minds of the past have approached their work. I want to provide a new way to see people and their routines. I also want to share my own struggles with creativity and productivity.
I have a lot of concerns about creative work and earning a living. How do you do meaningful creative work while also earning a living? Is it better to devote yourself wholly to a project or to set aside a small portion of each day? And when there doesn’t seem to be enough time for all you hope to accomplish, must you give things up or can you learn to condense activities, to do more in less time, to ‘work smarter, not harder’, as my dad is always telling me?
I have tried to provide examples of how a variety of brilliant and successful people have confronted similar challenges. I wanted to show how grand creative visions translate to small daily increments; how one’s working habits influence the work itself, and vice versa.
This book is about people’s routines. It’s about the circumstances of creative activity, not the product; it deals with manufacturing rather than meaning. But it’s also, inevitably, personal. I have documented all of my sources in the Notes section, which I hope will also serve as a guide to further reading.

Howard became a palaeontologist because he was inspired by a rise in interest rates when he was young. He found out that he wanted to become a palaeontologist when he was at university. He studied delicate creatures revealed on the surface of grey rocks. He got a job as a palaeontologist at a college in London. He often found himself contrasting the orderly nature of his professional life with the anarchy of private concerns.
One day, Howard's briefcase was stolen. He was fuming and returned to the college. He made an explanatory phone call and postponed the lecture. He reported the theft to the appropriate authorities and then went for a restorative coffee. He joined a colleague who was entertaining a visiting curator from the Natural History Museum in Nairobi. And thus it was that Howard learned of the recently acquired collection of fossils, the study of which would provide him with his greatest challenge and ensure his professional future.

Charles Spence is a Professor of Experimental Psychology at Oxford University in the UK. He has studied how the senses interact to form our perception of flavour. Through his studies, he has influenced what we eat and drink. He has also studied how the environment affects taste.
Spence has written a book called The Perfect Meal, which is packed with insights that are fascinating to anyone in possession of an appetite. It includes information about how much we eat when eating with others and how music can affect taste.
Spence's lab is un-space-age. It has soundproof booths and stacks of ancient-looking audio-visual equipment. He can afford to work more creatively with cooks because he keeps his overheads low.
Spence is currently helping famous brands through reductions in salt and sugar. He points out that it is in their interests to help loyal customers stay alive for longer.
What, one wonders, are dinner parties like in the Spence household? They're all extensions of the lab to Spence.

Our brains are very busy these days. We have a lot of information to deal with, including facts, rumors, and things that are not true. We also do more things ourselves now than we used to. For example, we make our own reservations and find things in shops. We do a lot of different things at once, but it turns out that this is not multitasking. Multitasking is a powerful and dangerous illusion. It actually makes us less efficient. It also increases the production of stress hormones and makes it harder to focus. If you are trying to focus on a task while there is an unread email in your inbox, your effective IQ can be reduced by almost 10 points. Multitasking also requires decision-making, which is also very hard on our brains. We rapidly spiral into a depleted state in which we can end up making truly bad decisions about something important.

In a zoo in Sweden, a chimpanzee named Santino would sometimes break up concrete into pieces and throw them at visitors. Was he being spiteful? In caves in the US, female bats help unrelated fruit bat mothers if they can’t find the right birthing position. Are they being caring? Fifty years ago, people thought that animals didn’t have consciousness or feelings. But recently that has partially changed. Thanks to research into the behaviour of bats, chimps, and other animals, emotions of animals have gone from being a taboo area of investigation to being tentatively explored. The new research has started a debate about whether animals can be said to have consciousness. This debate stimulates a second, much less abstract, one: not of consciousness, but conscience – a person’s moral sense of right and wrong that guides their behaviour. If, as this research seems to imply, cows enjoy problem-solving, what does it mean for the production and consumption of beef? The observations may not be disputed, but the interpretation of them is. There are different views on what the new research means for the production and consumption of beef. Some people believe that we should stop eating meat altogether, while others believe that we should at the very least re-evaluate our view of animal cognition. The debate about animal consciousness is a complex one and there is no easy answer.

Critical thinking is a way of understanding what we read or listen to in a deeper way. It involves interacting with the text and thinking about the meaning of the words and ideas. There is a belief that argument is a way of finding the truth. Although technology can help us store and process information, it can also make it more difficult to think critically.
Reading enhances thinking and engages the imagination in a way that visual media such as video games and television do not. It develops imagination, induction, reflection, and critical thinking, as well as vocabulary. However, visual media can also improve some types of information processing.
Many people – particularly those who are younger – wind up underachieving and not making the most of their capabilities because of the way society views technology. It’s time to take a closer look at technology and understand the subtleties of how it affects thinking and analysis.

When Matthew Crawford is not writing or thinking about how we ought to live, he works as a motorcycle mechanic. He wrote two books about the benefits of manual trades and philosophy. One of his books is a quiet masterpiece about the benefits of the manual trades. The other book is a philosophical treatise on how to cope with modernity.
Crawford says that our attention is being pulled in many directions. We are being prevented from deciding what we want to be at the forefront of our mind. It is becoming more and more difficult to think or spend time remembering conversations we’ve had. And because everyone is trying to protect themselves from the irritation of constantly being interrupted, we close ourselves off and no longer want to do simple things like chat to strangers.
Crawford's proposed solution has two parts. First, we need regulation of noise and distraction in public space. More importantly, though, Crawford advocates skilled practices as a way of engaging with the world in a more satisfying way.

What do you do for a living? It's a common question that we use to define ourselves. When you're a philosopher, it's a little harder to deal with. It's because describing yourself as a philosopher sounds rather pretentious. However, philosophers are no different from the masses. They have established themselves as people who judge the activities of others and celebrate intellectual life.
Philosophy can help people look a little more closely at the practices and behaviours that define their lives. Sometimes this might reveal something we already know; at other times we might discover that our beliefs are hard to justify. Either way, merely by examining these ideas, we’ll be doing something for the benefit of everyone.

Foodies, gourmands, chefs and others who love food might expect that thinking critically about what and how we eat can contribute to culinary pleasure. However, philosophical discussions of food have often been about other topics, such as the acquisition of knowledge or the pursuit of pleasure. Food is inherently social and cultural. It is shared with those in our communities and provides us with dining companions and infrastructure. Ethical issues related to food include what we should eat and the extent to which cooking in restaurants and in the home differ. Cooking in the home is often more intimate and inclusive, while cooking for a living has different obligations. Food and dining can also play a role in bridging cultural gaps. We can come to appreciate others by learning to enjoy their food and forge personal bonds with people from other cultures by coming together to eat.

Rob Daviau is a US-based game designer who creates legacy board games. These games are different from traditional board games because they have a permanent impact on the game. For example, in one game, players might have to rip up cards, deface the board, or open packets containing new rules. The games play out over a fixed number of sessions and long-held grudges become woven into the fabric of the game.
Legacy board games were not expected to go mainstream, but most players love the concept. They see it as one of the biggest advances in game design for several years. The appeal of an unfolding adventure trumped any concerns about longevity.
The legacy format draws on video games and the demand for episodic entertainment fuelled by popular TV series. Daviau feels a sense of ownership, but he is keen to see where others take the idea.

Once upon a time, there was an octopus named Inky who lived in a tank at the New Zealand National Aquarium. One night, Inky managed to escape from his tank and swim across the floor to a drain that led to the Pacific Ocean. It was a story that was shared online and was popular among children.
One of the reasons why people find stories like Inky's so interesting is because they involve anthropomorphism, which means treating animals like humans. Anthropomorphism is often thought to be unscientific, but Dr. Frans de Waal believes that it is not. He argues that animals have many of the same abilities as humans, such as the ability to consider the past and the future, to demonstrate empathy and self-awareness, and to anticipate the motives of others.
De Waal also points out that humans have a lot of negative habits, such as tearing down animal habitats, polluting land and water, and developing methods of rearing livestock that ignore the welfare of the animals. However, he believes that we are emerging from this dark period and learning to think of animal cognition as being on the same spectrum, though not necessarily at the same point, as that of humans.

Once upon a time, there was a technology called robotics that has the potential to change the world. Robots have already been used in the automotive and manufacturing industries for many years. Experts say that in the next few years, robots will be used in many other industries. This technology will definitely impact lower-skilled people, but it also presents an opportunity for companies to grow and create new jobs.
In order to prepare for the future, we need to invest in education and training programs. We also need to develop new regulatory frameworks to ensure our safety and privacy. With millions of jobs at risk and a worldwide employment crisis looming, it is only logical that we should turn to education to understand and prepare for the robotic workforce of tomorrow.

Because it's there, the mountaineer George Mallory is said to have said when asked why he wanted to climb Mount Everest. People have a desire to understand why anyone would participate in such a seemingly meaningless and life-threatening pursuit. Climbing can be a very confining and restricting activity, yet it can also give a feeling of freedom. There is an apparent paradox in many forms of climbing. Climbing can help cultivate important virtues such as courage, humility and respect for the environment. One further belief worth exploring is that climbers who do not rely on other people or technology to help them, have to be totally committed to their goal in order to succeed.

Alfred Brendel is a famous pianist who has been playing classical music for many years. He is known for his intellectual and disciplined personality. Brendel has written and played a lot of music, but he has not taught very much. Those who knew him best saw a playful side to his character, but that was seldom on display in his concerts.
Brendel has a young student named Kit Armstrong. Kit is a restless and impatient young man who is always learning new things. He is also a gifted composer. Brendel is impressed by Kit's ability to listen to his own playing and his sensitivity to sound. He says that Kit is "exceptional" and that he has a "phenomenal memory."
Brendel is now 80 years old and he is still playing music. He says that he is "very grateful" for his career and that he is "happy to have been able to do what I love."

My grandparents' garden was a beautiful place. It was on the bank of a river and sloped gently down towards the water. You couldn’t reach the river but you could hear the sound of the water and the birds that sang in the trees above. I imagined that all gardens were like this – a place of escape, peace and solitude.
My father was a quiet and withdrawn person. He had a lot of phrases that he liked to use, one of them being 'It’s immaterial to me'. He was probably disappointed that he hadn’t made more of his life. He left school without qualifications and became apprenticed to a plumber. It was not something he was passionate about.
I always wanted to like the piano but it did its best to intimidate me. The only thing I did like about it were the two brass candlesticks that jutted out from the front. I would often spend time imagining myself playing the piano, but I never had the opportunity to learn.
I wanted out of school as soon as possible. One day my father announced, 'They’ve got a vacancy for an apprentice gardener in the Parks Department. I thought you might be interested.' In one brief moment Dad had gone against his better judgement. He might still have preferred it if I became a carpenter. But I like to feel that somewhere deep down inside him was a feeling that things might just turn out for the best. If I stuck at it.

Lawrence MacEwen lives on the Isle of Muck, a small island in Scotland. The island is surrounded by the Atlantic Ocean. There is a strong wind blowing, and the waves are high. MacEwen's sheepdog, Tie, is playing with the sheep. The wind is very strong, but MacEwen is not worried. He is happy on his island. MacEwen is giving me a tour of his neighbourhood. He tells me about the different islands and the weather. He also tells me about his family and his farm. The island life is not perfect, but MacEwen is still happy. He has a good life, and he is grateful for the things he has.

The game design industry was once a niche hobby, but it has become more popular in recent years. It is not easy to get into, but it is expanding. To be successful in the game design industry, you need to have a strong passion for games, creativity, and technical skills. You can also get help from a postgraduate course or network with people in the industry.
There are many different ways to get involved in the game design industry. You can start by making your own games. You can also volunteer to help out at local game events. If you have a lot of creativity and technical skills, you may be able to get a job as a game designer.

Since I was a child, I have always wanted to play football. My dad encouraged me to play, and I'm grateful that he didn't push me too hard. I had a friend who was also passionate about football, but he stopped playing and hasn't been involved in the sport since. I'm glad that I didn't have that happen to me. I have worked hard to improve my skills, and I know that with practice, anyone can achieve great things.
I also used to play other sports at school, but football was my favorite. I want to make sure that my son has the same opportunities that I had, so I'm trying to read him books even though he's far too young to sit still for long enough. I hope that he doesn't take after me in that way.
I have a lot of money, but I don't have all the answers. After I stop playing, I think I'll have a year off or perhaps even longer, doing the things I haven't been able to do all these years. I want to go skiing the day after I stop playing, but I can't do that now because if I were to break a leg on the ski slopes and couldn't play football again, I wouldn't be insured.

It was because of Sam Carter that we were living at Reef Point. Sam was my father’s agent in Los Angeles. He offered to find somewhere cheap for us to live. The beach had been deserted since the warm weather had been blanketed by sea fogs. Reef Point was seldom patronised by the casual day tripper. There were a lot of people at the beach now. My father was hard at work trying to write a script to a deadline. I moved out onto the beach, taking a book to read, and Rusty for company. Rusty was my dog. We had a lot of fun playing together. Sometimes though, there were things that he had obviously not dug up – a new sneaker, a bright beach-towel. We had been swimming that day. The sun was setting and it was getting cooler. We sat watching the surfers. They had been at it all day, but it seemed they would never tire. One surfer in particular caught my eye. She had a style that made all the others look like clumsy amateurs. But now she seemed to decide to call it a day and rode in on a final wave. I talked to her. She was friendly but never interested until I mentioned Tall as the Morning.

Violet Hetherington was standing in a queue at the dock in Southampton. The queues were long and there was a lot of waiting passengers. There was a problem with the computer system and the atmosphere became dark. Some people were patient, but most people were unhappy. Violet felt that the whole idea of the cruise was a mistake. She was also annoyed by the loss of her phone. She couldn’t call anyone because her numbers were stored in her phone. She was going to be in trouble because she had no other means of finding numbers she needed in New York. But she was thankful that she had a balcony in her room. She had been anxiously rehearsing what to say if it had not.

When John Maloof bought a box of old photo negatives at an estate auction, he discovered the mystery of Vivian Maier. Maier was a street photographer with a keen eye for capturing compelling images. Maloof has amassed an archive of Maier’s life and work, which includes her cameras, film, prints, negatives, movies, and audiotapes.
Maier was born in 1926 and spent much of her childhood in France. She returned to New York in 1951 and came to Chicago to work as a nanny. Maier was a private person but had a strong passion for photography. She always had a camera with her and dressed in oversized coats, broad-brimmed hats, and stout shoes.
Maier’s work is the purest form of art. None of it was done for any commercial reason. Her images lean toward women, children, the old, the poor, and the abstract. Maloof often wonders if he’ll ever work his way through all the negatives. Inspired by Maier’s architectural shots, Maloof actually went out on the street and began to take his own pictures.

When a novel is described as ambitious, it often means that it is not successful. However, this is not the case with Eleanor Catton’s book, The Luminaries. The book is set during the 1860s in New Zealand. A series of crimes have been committed, and a council of 12 men has convened to solve them. The plot is complex and exciting. Catton said she set out to write a murder mystery, not a historical novel, but found the past offered more opportunities for complications and misunderstandings for her characters to deal with. The book is long, but it is worth reading. It is a fun and engaging read that will keep you on the edge of your seat.

As a boy, Jonny Kinkead loved to play the guitar. He learned to play his brother’s guitar when he was eleven and wanted to learn the bass guitar when he was sixteen. He built his own bass guitar and started making guitars for a living.
Jonny’s passion for music and his skills in woodworking led him to build his own business. He started by making model boats and aeroplanes and then moved on to building guitars. He was able to charge more for his guitars as he gained a reputation for being one of the best guitar-makers around.
Even now, almost forty years later, Jonny describes what he does as ‘still scratching a living’. He admits he can never actually turn out more than ten guitars a year, which inevitably restricts his earnings. But he is proud of his work and believes that developing a career is more straightforward for today’s new guitar-makers in the UK.

Any conversation about English conversation often begins with the weather. It is a traditional way to start a conversation in English. The writer Dr. Johnson said that "When two Englishmen meet, their first talk is of the weather." This observation is still accurate today. However, most people who write about the English "obsession" with the weather make a mistake. They assume that our conversations about the weather are actually about the weather. This is not true. Our conversations about the weather are not really about the weather at all. They are a form of "grooming talk."
There are certain fixed contexts in which weather-speak is used. It can be used as a simple greeting, as an ice-breaker leading to conversation on other matters, or as a "default" or "filler" topic when conversation on other matters dries up.

Alice Leader was standing in front of the remains of a Roman wall in Britain. She was explaining to her class of 12- and 13-year-olds what an extraordinary feat of engineering it was. The wall was very long and tall. It was built a long time ago. Alice felt her answers were unsatisfactory. She wrote a novel to add context and human interest to life at the Wall in Roman times. She retired from teaching and started writing full-time. Alice loves teaching and writing. She sees her writing as an extension of teaching. She is inspired by her love of children and her desire to fill a gap in today’s fiction for children.

To raise money for charity, two brothers, Jonny and Alistair Brownlee, were challenged to take part in a unique race. The race would set man against car and brother against brother. It took place in the wild and mountainous Yorkshire Dales of northern England.
Jonny raced in a car on the roads, while Ali raced across the country on a mountain bike. The race started at a beautiful lake and finished at Yorkshire’s highest road.
There were some obstacles during the race. The first obstacle was a giant tractor that lumbered out of a field and onto the road. The second obstacle was a steep hill that forced Alistair to dismount and carry his bike up the hill.
In the end, Alistair won the race. He was very happy to have won.

The silence on Centre Court at the Wimbledon tennis championships is very quiet. You can bounce the ball, toss it up to serve, and hit it. The trimmed grass, the rich history, the ancient stadium, the players dressed in white, and the respectful crowds all combine to enclose and cushion you from the outside world. The quiet of the Centre Court is good for your game. It helps you to focus and concentrate on the point you’re playing.
The silence is broken by a shock of noise when a point’s done. There is applause, cheers, and people shouting your name. You hear them, but as if from some place far off. You don’t register that there are fifteen thousand people hunched around the arena, tracking every move your opponent and you make. You are so focused you have no sense at all that there are millions watching you around the world as you play Roger Federer in the 2008 Wimbledon final – the biggest match of your life.

A young Englishwoman named Jane Goodall arrived in Africa in early 1957. She spent most of her life in Africa and became known for her work as a scientist, activist, and environmentalist.
In 1963, Jane Goodall's fame grew when a series of articles and documentaries were made about her chimpanzee research. Her writing for a popular audience, including award-winning children’s books and the bestseller In the Shadow of Man, has also increased her fame.
Jane Goodall's work has had a significant impact on the way we study animals and ourselves. She opened the door to our understanding of the social and emotional lives of chimpanzees. Her long-term study of wild apes along the shores of Lake Tanganyika in Gombe State, Nigeria, has been praised as one of the Western world's great scientific achievements.
Even as a child, there were hints that Jane Goodall would become a biologist. One day, she crawled inside a henhouse to find out how hens lay eggs. This event is often seen as the beginning of her career as a biologist.

During a conversation, Shirley Ford speaks to me in different voices, including the voices of a cheeky 8-year-old boy, his tired mother, and a very fast-talking alien. Her voices are recognisable to people who have seen children’s TV and cartoons, and to people who have seen computerised employee programmes about health and safety.
Shirley talks about what it takes to do voiceovers. She says that there is more to it than just being able to do funny voices. You also have to bring the script to life for an audience who can’t see you.
After school, Shirley enrolled on a drama course and had some occasional work singing jingles for TV adverts. One day, she was suggested to try out for the part of a rabbit in the soundtrack for a cartoon. She ended up getting a major part and realised she could do voices and that voiceover work might be the way to go.
The competition for work is fierce, and a good showreel is essential. Shirley recommends attending ‘specialist workshops’ and believes a passion for human sound is fundamental.

People often ask me how I became a cartoonist. It's a dream job that many people have. But most people eventually give up on their dreams and consider more realistic professions. To become a cartoonist, you don't need a university degree or much money. You just need your brain, your hand and something that makes a mark. If you feel that doing anything else would be impossible, then cartooning might be the right job for you. But it's a tough job and not everyone can do it. You need to be creative and business-savvy. If you're not comfortable selling your work, you probably shouldn't become a cartoonist.

Twenty years ago, I was moving house and had a lot of things to get rid of. I decided to throw away an electric guitar that my dad had bought me for my 16th birthday. I felt sad about throwing it away, but I took it to the rubbish dump and was about to put it on a pile of rubbish. Suddenly, a young man came up to me and asked if I was going to throw it away. I said yes and he asked if he could have it. I gave it to him and felt sad that I had thrown it away.
A few months later, I received an email from someone I didn't know. It was from a dealer and restorer of guitars called Keith Rushton. He said he had my guitar and offered to sell it back to me. I was so happy to get my guitar back and I started playing it again.
I had forgotten all about my dad's habit of putting name-and-address stickers on everything I had, including my guitar. My dad had been very keen for me to learn the classical guitar, but I couldn't make much progress. So I switched to the electric guitar, playing undemanding stuff. Now that I'm learning it again, I guess I'll have to form a band.

There has been a lot of talk about sleep lately. Sleep is very important for our mental, physical, and social well-being. It seems that people who have the hardest time sleeping are the ones who most appreciate how important sleep is. Dreams are important too. They help us find new patterns and create combinations that break through our usual habits of thinking.
When you wake up in the morning, you may have forgotten your dreams, but they can still have a positive impact on your day. If you write or create art, you may find that you are able to write or create more easily after a dream. Even if you don't write or create art, you can still benefit from dreaming. Dreams can help you to think creatively and flexibly, which can be helpful in many aspects of life.

It was twenty years ago that Susie Ray left London for a small coastal town in south-west England. She is a copyist artist who can reproduce the richness of an early-20th-century impressionist masterpiece as easily as the brilliance of a 16th-century Caravaggio portrait.
Susie has been in great demand for her copies of famous paintings. She has painted the works of numerous great artists, including Renoir, Monet, and Van Gogh. Her reproductions are so faithful that art experts mistake them for the originals.
However, Susie has never been tempted to pass off her copies as the real thing. She believes that doing it badly would be letting the artist down. She also knows that making fakes tends to end up in trouble.
Susie has always been open about what she does. She will make it look as authentic as possible, but she will put her own signature on the back of the canvas.
When younger painters approach Susie for advice, she stresses the importance of learning to draw and to represent things accurately. She also emphasises how much she’s studied to be able to do what she does.

During Ellen MacArthur's racing days, she loved the sea more than anything else. She had a special connection with her boats. They worked together like one. When she was on land, she felt that life was trivial. She often wanted to be back on the ocean, testing herself against the forces of nature. After she came second in a big race, she took you down into her boat to show you how she prepared for the race. She talked about the careful planning that had gone into provisioning and housekeeping. The boat was her world and she looked after it because her life depended on it. Now, she sees the world as a boat. It is a small, beautiful, and fragile thing whose supplies are running out. She has been working to save the planet. She believes that we have to design a way of not using things up. She also started a charity to give young people the vision to rethink and redesign a sustainable future.

Jordan Romero is 13 years old and wants to be the youngest person to climb Mount Everest. If he succeeds, he could become one of the most famous teenagers of his generation. Young people are spending more time on computers and games consoles, so Jordan hopes to inspire kids to climb their own mountains. He also wants to inspire kids to venture outdoors. Jordan’s team for the climb includes his father, Paul, and mother, Karen. They call themselves 'Team Romero.' If Jordan can climb Everest and Vinson Massif in Antarctica, he will become the youngest person to have climbed the Seven Summits. Few people achieve this under the age of thirty. Jordan has already climbed five of the Seven Summits and might actually do it before his teenage years are over.
There are some concerns about Jordan’s climb. Many people think that it is not a good idea to take a young child up such a dangerous mountain. They worry about the emotional strength and experience of a teenager. However, Jordan’s parents believe that their own experience as climbers will help them to guide their son safely. They also believe that watching Jordan develop will give them confidence.
Jordan is motivated by his goal of becoming the youngest person to climb Mount Everest. He is also motivated by the fact that every adventure is blogged about and every climb turns into a record-setting challenge. However, Jordan also knows that achievement too often replaces enjoyment during such challenges. If he wants to inspire others, he has to play the media game and offer something spectacular.

When you see a teenager with an MP3 player, it's probably not classical music they're listening to. Most people our age can name a lot of pop groups, but few of us know who Brahms was. I started doing a music degree, but the people on my course know no more about classical music than anyone else. If you don’t know who wrote the music, you are unlikely to own any recordings of their work. Classical music just doesn’t hold much attraction for most people, and that is particularly true of teenagers. There are a few reasons why teenagers don’t like classical music. First, the pace and rhythm of classical music are too slow for us. Second, classical music is too long and difficult to pay attention to. Third, the subject matter of classical music is not as appealing as pop music. Finally, the way we listen to music has changed. Nowadays, you can find any music you want at the click of a mouse, and yet the sound track to our lives is rarely classical.

Bonnie Wyndham got out of her mother’s car and looked at Almonside School. It was a funny school, with lots of buildings and trees. There was a riding centre where the horses were kept. Bonnie treated horses with respect. She looked at the horses and judged them. She rode a horse named Maverick. It was a great horse, and she felt like a queen. She went round and round the paddock. The rhythm was exhilarating.

I met Cody Simpson before. He is a 15-year-old Australian singer. He has already released a number of successful songs. How did a laid-back surfer guy end up on a stage in front of thousands and thousands of fans?
Cody started playing the guitar and writing songs when he was young. He was also a very talented swimmer. He was training hard with some of the best coaches and putting his focus into perfecting his sport. But then record labels came calling, and he had a tough choice to make. He had to choose between staying in Australia and continuing swimming, or taking a huge risk and moving with his entire family to the US.
Cody decided to take the plunge and move to the US. He gave up one dream in the hope of making another one come true. Although his family keep out of the spotlight and aren’t directly involved in his career, they are there in the background. Success, in whatever career you choose, comes from a willingness to say ‘yes’ to your big break, even when it’s a little scary to do so.

I woke up early and looked at the river. The ice was shining in the sunlight. I helped my grandfather to protect the buildings from flooding. I worked with many people in the town to lift the sandbags. It was a lot of work, but I was able to do it. My grandfather didn’t notice me much. I saw a boy on the river bank. He was trying to balance on an ice shelf. I was worried about him. I put on my wetsuit and jacket and went to the river. I found a lucky chain that my grandfather gave me. It is a special chain. I kept it close to me. I went to the kitchen and ate breakfast. My mom smiled at me. She said that I was up early for a Saturday. I went downstairs and stepped outside. I hurried towards the boathouse.

**
Mum caught Jess by the arm and asked her to come with her to the study. There was a painting on the table. It was one of Grandpa’s, but it was unlike anything he had done before. The picture was strange and beautiful. There was a river in the picture. It was not a real river, but it was a fantasy river. The riverbank was green. There were no animals or people in the picture. It felt right that way. There seemed no place for living things in this remote vision. Yet, Jess was captivated. She thought of the coming of autumn after a long, rich summer. Mum spoke again. The picture had a name. It was called 'River Boy.' The words seemed to carry a strange resonance. Jess knew what Grandpa’s response would have been. He would have said that painting is hard enough work as it is without having to explain every picture to everyone. And he would have said that artists should not have to explain their pictures to every Tom, Dick, and Harry who came along.

**
When I woke up this morning, I didn't mean to damage the carpet. It just seemed like a good idea at the time, as things so often do. I was trying to find a way of fitting my corner cabinet into a corner. Gran had given me the cabinet when she moved out of her house into a flat. It's really cute! I keep my collection of shells and fossils and interesting stones there.
The problem was, the cabinet was too tall. If I could only slice a couple of centimetres off the bottom of it... That was when it came to me. If I couldn't slice anything off Gran’s cabinet, how about cutting a hole in the carpet? It just seemed like the obvious solution. What Dad calls lateral thinking. I reckoned he would be quite pleased with me. He is always telling us to ‘think outside the box’. And that was exactly what I was doing!

The novel 'The Borrowers' is about a family of tiny people who live hidden in the walls and floors of a house. They secretly borrow things from the normal-sized people in order to survive. When the author asked me to direct a TV adaptation of the novel, I knew it was going to be hard to live up to people’s expectations. The most important thing was getting the scale right. The Borrowers are ten times smaller than humans, so I had to make sure that the actors looked small. I also had to get the costumes right. The costumes were made out of heavy canvas material so that they stuck out in the way that dolls’ clothes do. Unfortunately, the weather was really hot during filming. But it all came together in the end, and I think the series was pretty successful in conveying the magic of the books.

Mom pulled to a stop at the corner of my new school, Palm Grove High School. She looked around nervously, looking for journalists that weren’t there. I told her everything was going to be fine. She kissed her fingertip and touched my cheek right before I got out of the car. Then she was off, leaving me alone with this whole new school and situation to deal with.
I walk in the school’s main office and get my schedule. English Literature, first period. Cool, I can deal with that. But I’m late. English is in Room 214, second floor. I studied the map the night before, as I didn’t want to look like a complete buffoon searching for my classes.
When I get to the door, I hear the teacher already taking roll. I slip in undetected and slide into the last desk in the second row. The girl next to me smiles. She scans over my very normal and, might I add, very clever outfit – jeans and a T-shirt. Ha! Nobody will ever suspect me now!
The teacher pauses in the roll taking. ‘Desert... McGraw?’ she says hesitantly. ‘Here.’ The teacher then smiles and introduces herself as Ms. Smigla. She talks a lot and eventually hands us our course outlines. After we review them and she tells us all about books we’re required to read this year, she actually gives us time to socialize! All teachers should realize the importance of this.

In the United States, teenage girls are expected to be Student Council presidents and have part-time jobs. Teenage boys and girls have a lot of responsibilities, including homework, tests, extracurricular activities, jobs, chores, and family obligations. They also have to deal with the pressure of trying to maintain a social life.
Teenagers today have a lot of stress. They have piles of homework, tests, and extra-curricular activities, jobs, chores, and responsibilities at home. They also have to try to maintain some sort of social life. Despite these stresses, teenagers still have to deal with negative stereotypes about them.
One teenager, Kristen Loose, says that people often make assumptions about teenagers. They think that all teenagers are lazy, disrespectful, and rebellious. However, Loose believes that this is not true. She says that teenagers today have a lot of responsibilities and that they are not lazy.
Another teenager, Lindamarie Olsen, says that she gets about 18 hours of leisure time a week. However, she does not spend most of her time on social media or television. Instead, she focuses much of her energy on volunteer work.
In 20 years, it is likely that the stereotype of teenagers will have changed. However, one thing is for sure, teenagers will continue to prove that they are capable of great things.

The teenage members of the Earth to Sky Calculus Club live in Bishop, a mountain town in the US, surrounded by wilderness. They have launched over fifty balloons to the edge of space. It's a long-running science project and a backcountry adventure. The teenagers get involved because it's part astronomy experiment and part adventure. I joined them one weekend in late spring. They were releasing a high-altitude balloon, hoping to record shooting stars.
A few things happen when the balloon goes up. First, it grows to the size of a small car. Then, it pops in a dramatic explosion. Finally, a parachute helps the equipment inside the lunch box land safely back on Earth.
Getting the lunch box back is not straightforward. It often lands somewhere in the middle of nowhere. To find it, the recovery team has to drive south of the Sierra and then back up the western side of the mountain range. It can take a long time to find the lunch box. But it's also a perfect opportunity to argue over the effects of atmospheric waves and share stories of adventure.

Chloe Morgan is a palaeontologist. She started her interest in the field when she was fifteen. She was inspired by her younger brother's interest in dinosaurs and by an article she read about recent discoveries. She felt that Palaeontology was a unique and rewarding career choice.
One day, Chloe met her first professional palaeontologist, Matt Cornelius. He was famous and approachable. She was nervous at first, but she felt more at ease when he showed her patience and willingness to listen.
Dinosaurs continue to fascinate us because they speak to our innate explorer instincts. They are also a reminder that there is still more out there to be discovered.
Chloe is passionate about sharing her knowledge and enthusiasm for Palaeontology with others. She likes to reach out to young people and explain the complexities of science. She believes that everyone has the potential to learn about science and that it is important to inspire young people to be curious and to explore new possibilities.

When you travel by car with your family, even when you're young, you know that you're not 'there yet.' Once you get there, it's not 'there' anymore, it's 'here.' If you really think there's a chance that you're 'there yet,' you should be asking 'Are we there yet? ' And parents often get tired of hearing that question over and over.
There are a lot of things you can do when you're travelling by car. You can watch DVDs, listen to music, or play puzzles. You can also act as co-pilot and help your parents adjust the radio station and temperature.
Sometimes, things can get out of control and a fight can break out. But your parents will usually be there to help you and keep you safe. And once you're finally 'there,' you'll see the grown-ups tumble out of the car and go as far away as they can from the kids.

John and Zuzi Morgan have a café in Oxford, UK, where people can enjoy coffee, cake, and play board games. They decided to turn their love of tabletop games into a full-time business because there is so much technology and people are busy on their mobile phones and gadgets. The games played in their café are called Eurogames. They are known for their gentle themes and easy rules.
One of the most successful Eurogames is Pandemic. It was created by Matt Leacock, a North American designer. Pandemic is a cooperative game where players must work together to solve global problems. It is a popular game because it is easy to learn and fun to play.
The growth of the video games industry has also helped to the success of Eurogames. Video games have become more popular than ever before, and this has led to a rise in the popularity of tabletop games. As a result, more people are open to playing games than ever before.
In John and Zuzi's café, tabletop gaming has become more than entertainment. It has become a way for people to share their love of games and interact with each other. This trend is set to continue in the future.

Jamie Scott is a musician who has written and produced some of the biggest UK hits of recent years. He started playing the guitar and singing at a young age. He was influenced by his mother, who was a singer, and the local radio station he listened to. At 17, he left school to try to make it as a performer. He was part of a duo with a friend, but they had to split up when the record labels only wanted him as a solo act. After a few near misses, he was signed to a music publisher and released a new album. He wrote songs for other artists and found success in that.

Tony Connor is a popular celebrity who is known for his amazing skills as a street trials cyclist. He is able to jump from tall heights and land safely in other strange locations. His stunts are filmed and posted online.
One Saturday morning, Tony met with the author in a BMX park. The local boys all knew exactly who he was, and people came to pay their respects. Tony is not always seen as a hero. Some people claim he's reckless and takes unnecessary risks. However, Tony is far from casual about the risks he runs. He knows that there are dangers involved in his sport, but he finds a way to overcome his fear and continue to compete.

**
Television presenter Helen Skelton has completed various dangerous challenges for charity, including a desert marathon run and a journey down the Amazon river in a tiny boat. For her latest challenge, Helen walked on a high wire, a long thin piece of metal, 66 meters above the ground. There was no safety net, only a belt around her waist attached to another wire above. To help her keep her balance and not to fall, she carried a long stick, weighing eight kilograms. Helen took lessons from an expert high-wire walker. Although she already had a few circus skills, she quickly discovered that high-wire walking was completely different. The training was a shock, said Helen. 'I didn’t realise how strong I’d need to be. Every day started at 8 am with a run up a steep hill; then came an hour of exercises, with another hour of them after my day practising on the wire. I also had to learn how to fall onto the wire so that if I slipped I could carry on. Every time I fell on the wire it hurt badly. But it was essential to keep a positive attitude: if I was nervous and started shaking, so would the wire.

**
In 2006, Jeff Somers began a journey around the world on a penny farthing, a bicycle with one big and one small wheel. He had already written a book about his experiences travelling around Canada in a 50-year-old car and was passionate about motor sport. To save money, Jeff rode to work on an old bicycle and used it to go to Amsterdam on holiday. The trip opened his eyes and he decided to see the world by bike. Jeff didn’t want a normal touring bike and he knew he wanted to build one himself. He finally set out in 2006 and was away for three years, having travelled through 23 countries on four continents. The best bit of the trip was arriving in Tibet and seeing Mount Everest. Despite all the challenges, Jeff now says, ‘if I could afford it, I would set off travelling again tomorrow on my penny farthing.’

I work at a university in the US. My team and I are learning more about water birds, particularly one called the American black duck. We have started using a new piece of equipment called a night-vision scope, which allows us to see the ducks in the dark. We are worried about black ducks mainly because their numbers have fallen hugely. We don’t know whether there’s enough food on the east coast for these animals. We have lots of information about their daytime activities, but nothing about what they do at night, because we simply haven’t had the equipment. But this new ‘scope’ will produce really clear pictures, even on moonless nights, so we’ll be able to find out more and make better decisions about looking after the area where they live based on what we learn. It is very hard work. There are four of us, each working six hours daily. We have studied ducks in different locations, and I have had to take a boat to some sites and make notes on every duck I see. The weather hasn’t helped – some nights are mild, but more often it’s wet. Oh, and it’s so quiet I’ve needed lots of coffee to stop me falling asleep! We’ve only missed one working day so far, because the snow was too deep even for our special snow vehicles. Still I like the challenge of it, especially compared to what the summer will bring – hours in a laboratory, where we’ll look at our results together. It’ll be hard to be stuck inside – but it’s essential to do this. And I wouldn’t change it for anything!

**
I work as a chocolate taster. My job is to make sure that customers get perfect bars of high-quality chocolate from the company I work for. Every week I receive samples of chocolate from the factory and I have to taste them to see if they are perfect. I also have to taste the raw materials that are used to make chocolate. I spend days choosing the most suitable ones to go into the chocolate. I have a kitchen where I can test and taste products I make. It’s wonderful to have a private space I can go off to during the day. No two days are the same in this job. Sometimes I am at the factory and others I’m out of the country buying raw materials. But that kind of variety, and lack of routine, is something I love about the job.
